captions.text:
What do we really mean by "near" and "far"?
In a way, distance is just a measure of how

hard it is to get between two points. The
harder to get from here to there, the more

Thinking about distance in multiple dimensions
is easy now!

In two spatial dimensions, a point a mile
north and a mile east is more distant than

one that's just a mile east - it's harder
to get to.

What about one space and one time dimension?
Easy as well!

Getting to a point a mile east in 10 minutes
is a lot harder than getting there in 10 hours

-
so one mile east and 10 minutes in the future

is way more distant than 1 mile east and a
day in the future.

And a point that's a mile east right now is
impossible to get to - so it's super distant!

But hold on - that would mean that 10 minutes
is farther away than 10 hours! Doesn't that

seem backwards? It kind of is - but it's the
way the universe works:

in special relativity, more time equals less
distance! So distance in time is negative!

And if you travel east and into the future
in such a way that the negative time & positive

space distances cancel out, your total distance
will be zero. And you'll be traveling at the

So how far away is tomorrow? It's closer than
you think.

title: Distance and Special Relativity: How far away is tomorrow?

comments.author: Wesgo111

comments.text:
What if I graph a time dimension and a space dimension and then plot two 
points: one a meter away and a second into the future and another at the 
same distance--a meter--but two seconds into the future?  I can easily draw 
two right-triangles and use the pythagorean theorem to calculate the 
distance from me to each of the points in question.  I find that the point 
one meter and one second into the future is sqrt(1m^2 + 1s^2) away while 
the other is sqrt(1m^2 + 4s^2) away from me.  Surely the second point is 
more distant in the way that was described in the video. ﻿
comments.author: Noah Jones

comments.text:
+Noah Jones What you have successfully shown is that spacetime is 
non-euclidean. The temporal dimension works very differently to the spatial 
dimension, and transforms differently from reference frame to reference 
frame. With the temporal dimension you can't use euclidean geometry to 
measure distances.
comments.author: TLJGames

comments.text:
On the other hand, if we consider speed, then we might have a starting 
point that makes more sense.  Suppose a I'm traveling at a rate of 
one meter per second.  This could be written mathematically is 1m / 1s.  It 
makes intuitive sense because if I maintain the same speed, I know, 
intuitively, that it would take 2 seconds to travel 2 meters.  Dividing 2m 
by 2s I get, again 1m / 1s.  

Now, if I increase the amount of time I take to get to that one-meter mark 
by one second, I find that I now have a ratio (or speed) of  one meter per 
two seconds (1m / 2s).  Which is greater, 1m / 1s or 1m / 2s?  

This illustrates that 2 seconds is actually closer with respect 
to space/time quotient than 1 second.

comments.text:
the question your title proposes is how one would measure how far you have 
moved in time by using a measurement for distance. there are two ways to 
approach this. one could say since the speed of light is the cosmic speed 
limit it is the maximum distance you can travel in one second therefore one 
second 299,792,458 meters. that is pretty far away and that is how far away 
you have to look in order to see one second into the past. but that is a 
whole lot of distance for everyone to be moving every second so how about 
we go with how far you are actually moving every second. if you are at the 
equator about 1,180,000 meters from earths rotation 30,000 meters from 
earth's orbit around the sun and 250,000 meters from the solar systems 
orbit so at the very least at earth's poles you are going 270,000 meters 
every second and at most at the equator you are going 1,350,000 meters 
every second. so that my friends is how far a second is (it will vary 
depending on which side of the earth you are on in relation to you orbit 
around the sun. and the position of the earth around the sun in relation to 
our orbit around our galaxy)﻿

This effect which I have described has to do with time dilation and 
synchronization .Of course does the effect of gravitational time dilation 
play an important role as well, if the planet on which they live has a

can disregard some of those effects. It should only show the existence and

explain what time actualy is and why the different slices change for us . 
Or in other words ,why we move from one slice to a parallel one. 

A flat space time does not necessarily mean a static universe. However, so 
because of the fact that the curvature decides which form the universe has( 
negative curvature = infinite size, positive curvature from mass and energy 
= finite , shaped like a sphere or hypertorus etc . ).  It applies that 
parallel photon lines would come closer inside curved space time and are 
always parallel inside a not-curved space. At the beginning of the universe 
, as the photons were created , it was spread all around through other 
radiatons and atoms etc. .So we could find out from the smallest shapes and 
pattern of the background radiation that the space should be infinite in 
size with a deviation from 1 percent. This shape can tell us about the 
curvature. It is like as if you would throw a stone on flat water and 
determine the waves. And the observation fits with our calculations.
It is very probable that the deviation is because of our not so precise 
measurements but many people think this indicates that we live on a finite 
universe. 
I think the infinite version is the case. Even if we lived on a sphere, the 
space in which it would be embedded would have been infinite in size , not 
considering the fact that we arent able to describe a 4-d sphere version 
with our mathematics.

So if space would be realy infinite in size, then one part of space is 
still able to expand inside itself.

comments.text:
+Buzz Werd I guess you didn't understand what I said. It's a perspective 
thing, you can view it as general relativity says, or you can just do as I 
said and modify the variables.

Both are equally valid as far as predictive power goes, mine just adds a 
few predictions that require testing.

If I ever meet a physicist and can get him/her to understand what I mean, 
then maybe it could be tested. Until then I'll just have to keep working 
and refining my hypothesis.

I'm only offering it here if anyone wants to take it on and claim it. 
Although I'm kinda regretting that, because if I'm right, then this might 
lead to more dangerous weaponry for the powers that shouldn't be.

But I'm not one for deleting my posts. And I doubt very much that this'll 
ever get any traction. So just read it as a different perspective on the 
same thing.

comments.author: Buzz Werd

comments.text:
Actually, there's no reason to assume time doesn't exists, without time, 
motions would be impossible. I do believe time is uniform throughout the 
universe though (ie, not affectable), and isn't relative to motion as 
relativity postulates. My reasoning is that thanks to emc2 we know that 
everything is made up of energy, and if you disregard the changed term for 
light as non-energy (as I've heard it said), then it's easier to think that 
energy only has one velocity, and that's C. And that when it has no or 
little mono-directional velocity (lateral?) it spends its speed in angular 
velocity instead, so that the two added together still equals to C (lateral 
+ angular). So the slower the 'particle' is in lateral velocity the 
stronger the effect of the strong force, thus the particle decays/lives at 
a faster pace (and also attracts the matter around it to itself, or for 
objects, contract themselves). Conversely, the higher the lateral velocity, 
the weaker the strong force, and the object expends itself (in the 
direction of motion), and any in system motion is slowed down. This gives 
rise to the same effects observed by relativity, without having to add a 
link between time and space.

comments.author: Solomon Ray

comments.text:
That is the classical view of space and time - they're completely separate 
dimensions with no relationship to each other. With general relativity 
comes the metric tensor, which describes spacetime as one, interconnected 
fabric of reality.

So spacetime separation between two events is:

ds^2 = dx^2 + dy^2 + dz^2 - c^2 dt^2

Notice how, in addition to the normal 3 spatial dimensions of x, y, and z, 
we have time included as well. This is how we can, in a way, "convert" 
temporal separation into spatial separation, and vice versa, using the 
conversation ratio of c, the speed of light.

comments.author: ダニエル

comments.text:
+ダニエル His idea of distance being how difficult to it is to get somewhere 
comes from the equation Work = Force x Distance. It is a purely 
physics-based idea. He is basically arguing you need to put in more work to 
get to a place in less time, but the actual mathematics of space-time 
distances (or intervals) is a little more involved.

comments.author: david gonzalez

comments.text:
First off, don't confuse "Unintelligent" with "Uneducated!" Just because 
you haven't learned something yet, doesn't mean you can't. My guess in your 
case is that it's the former, not the latter.
Second, there's a reason this is called "MinutePhysics." :P Not only is it 
sixty seconds long, it also deals with a tiny portion of each problem (I 
like little puns like that. :P ) The point is to overcome our brief 
attention span to get us interested enough it a topic to go research it on 
our own, and that's exactly what I recommend you do.

comments.author: Dan G

comments.text:
Confused... how is distance a measure of how difficult it is to cover a 
distance? If an object is one mile east and 1 min in the future then you 
have already measured the time it takes to get one mile and therefore it is 
not just a distance but a time and a distance and should not be compared 
with an object that is 1 mile east and 1 day in the future. A min can never 
be further than an hour because a min and one hour are 60 sec and 60 min 
respectively and that never changes no matter how far something travels in 
that period.﻿

comments.text:
It is just to show that it is contrary to the claim of many astronomers 
that Newton's theory predicted black holes through the Mitchell-Laplace 
dark body.
comments.author: Scientific Fraud

comments.text:
It is routinely alleged that the black hole has an escape velocity. Often 
it is claimed that this is c at the 'event horizon'. On the other hand it 
is also alleged that nothing can even leave the black hole. Thus it is 
alleged that the BH has simultaneously an escape velocity and does not have 
an escape velocity. That is impossible. Also, if the escape velocity is c, 
as is often claimed, then light must escape! Yet on the other hand it is 
alleged that light cannot even leave a BH. Contra-hype!
comments.author: Scientific Fraud
